Award.AwardTitle: Proposal for DPF2015: Meeting of the American Physical Society Division of Particle and Fields at the University of Michigan; August 4-8, 2015.
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support to the University of Michigan for the biannual Meeting of the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Particles and Fields (DPF). The objective of the Division of Particles and Fields (DPF) of the American Physical Society (APS) is the "study of fundamental particles and fields, their structure, their interactions and interrelationships, the design and development of high energy accelerators, and the design and development of instrumentation techniques for high energy physics" (from http://www.aps.org/units/dpf/. The DPF Meeting is a biannual event which brings together physicists working in all of those areas to present results and exchange ideas. NSF support will be used to facilitate the attendance of students and members of under-represented groups at the meeting.

The scientific program will include a combination of plenary and parallel sessions in physics sub-disciplines such as Particle Accelerators, Beyond the Standard Model (BSM), Computing in High Energy Physics, Charge Parity (CP) Violation, Detector Research and Development, Electroweak Physics, Higgs Sector, Field and String Theory, Neutrino Physics, Particle Astrophysics and Cosmology, Low Energy Searches for (BSM) Physics, Physics at Lepton Colliders, Heavy Flavor Physics, Top Quark Physics, Hadron Spectroscopy, Perturbative and non-Perturbative Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), Outreach, Careers, and Women and Minorities in Physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We requested $4.5K of financial support to assist staging DPF2015, the biannual Meeting of the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Particles and Fields (DPF), at the University of Michigan in August ,4-8, 2015. The funds were to be used toward financial aid for students or under-represented minorities, either in the form of registration fee reduction or lodging expenses subsidies.

The conference was a resounding success. We had a total of 480 participants, attending morning plenary sessions with invited speakers and presenting their results at parallel session on topics like Particle Accelerators, Beyond the Standard Model (BSM), Computing in High Energy Physics, Detector R&D, Electroweak, Top and Higgs Physics, Field and String Theory, Neutrino Physics, Particle Astrophysics and Cosmology, Heavy Flavor Physics, Perturbative and Non-Perturbative QCD, Outreach, Careers, Women and Minorities in Physics.

Subsidies covering for lodging expenses and/or reduced registration fee were granted to a total of 57 postdocs and students out of 60 applicants. The estimated amount of total financial aid was $15K.  The funds from this grant were distributed among about 18 students.

The total conference budget, including expenses for renting of venues and equipment, conference provided meals and parking, public lecture, outreach events, secretarial fees and advertising, amounted to $179K. The registration fee covered 85% of the total, with other awards from the American Physical Society, the Department of Energy and various sources at University of Michigan covering the remaining 15%.
